history.content: You have to Phase II them. Many students, including declared majors, do this all the time. Don't worry about it, though  - you'll get into 170 and 188, if you phase II them.
You have to Phase II them. Many students, including declared majors, do this all the time. Just make sure you Phase II them. Don't worry about it, though, you'll get into 170 and 188. You'll be fine.

children.subject: Yes, it is. Historically, courses start small and get expanded later on. It's not a guarantee but it almost always happens. Scaling CS courses is just a function of adding more TAs and more rooms for sections. The lecture halls are always big enough to accomodate those who want to attend lecture.

Er, no, most upper-divisions don't get expanded. The funding to add more TAs doesn't appear from nowhere.

And CS188 is already at the lecture hall's capacity.
Also: considering that 188 this semester was already a bit smaller than usual, I would suspect that it'll be harder to get into next semester than normal, due to increased demand.
But 188 seems to have not many seats next semester (only 200+), is it still possible for undeclared to get in 188?

history.content:
We will wait until major declarations (not necessarily appeals but the first round of approvals) have been completed before we purge the waitlist of non-majors.  (The calendar allows us to do this for fall enrollments even if that doesn't quite work out for spring enrollments.)

While waiting until phase 2 might work out, you'll increase your chances if you use your phase 1 units.

I'm going to be declaring this semester, but enrollment happens before the declaration goes through.

I'm planning to try and take 170 with 188 next semester, am I allowed to phase 1 these or do I have to phase 2 them?
history.subject: Enrolling in UpperDivs while still undeclared
